Question_1.Context: The study focused on measuring the ductility of high-carbon steel wires less than 0.296 mm in diameter using capstan-type grippers and tensile testing. The validity of using capstan-type grippers was discussed.
Question_1.Question: What method was used to fasten the high-carbon steel wires for tensile testing?
Question_1.Source: Capstan-type grippers are conventionally recommended for gripping non-metal fibers but can be applied to a fine metal wire even though the tensile strength of these fine wires is 6.3–7.0 GPa and is much greater than the strength of non-metal fibers.

Question_2.Context: The study aimed to establish a reliable method for measuring the ductility of fine metal wires. It discussed the conditions verified during the experiment.
Question_2.Question: What was the maximum error observed in the calculation of uniform elongation?
Question_2.Source: The maximum error of uniform elongation was 0.21%.

Question_3.Context: The study investigated the accuracy of calculating elongation using stroke increment and the stroke at 0 N.
Question_3.Question: How was the stroke at 0 N calculated?
Question_3.B: Using the slope of the stroke increment and the testing force curve
Question_3.Source: The stroke at 0 N testing force can be extrapolated using the slope of the stroke increment and the testing force curve.

Question_4.Context: The study discussed the relationship between chuck distance and uniform elongation for different wire diameters.
Question_4.Question: What was the difference in uniform elongation caused by chuck distance?
Question_4.Source: The difference in uniform elongation caused by chuck distance was not confirmed.

Question_5.Context: The study focused on calculating the reduction of area using SEM images of fractured pieces.
Question_5.Question: How was the reduction of area calculated?
Question_5.A: By the diameter before tensile testing
Question_5.B: By the diameter at the most constricted point
Question_5.Source: Reduction of area can be calculated using the radius of the wire at a uniform deformation portion, the radius at the most constricted point, and the uniform elongation.

Question_6.Context: The study verified the accuracy of the reduction of area calculation method using SEM images of fractured pieces.
Question_6.Question: What was the measurement error observed in the reduction of area calculation?
Question_6.Source: The measurement error of reduction of area was 1.9%.

Question_7.Context: The study discussed the application of the measurement method to other metal wires under 1 mm in diameter.
Question_7.Question: What was the highest tensile strength among the metal wires discussed in the study?
Question_7.Source: Since high-carbon steel wires have the highest tensile strength among metal wires...

Question_8.Context: The study concluded by presenting the developed methods for measuring elongation and reduction of area.
Question_8.Question: What was the maximum error observed in the measurement of reduction of area?
Question_8.Source: The measurement error was at most 1.9%.

Question_9.Context: The study discussed the conditions verified during the experiment, especially for wires less than 0.1 mm.
Question_9.Question: What was the validity that was demonstrated regarding the stroke increment?
Question_9.C: Validity of regarding the stroke increment as the extension of the wire
Question_9.Source: Furthermore, the validity of regarding the stroke increment as the extension was demonstrated.

Question_10.Context: The study verified the conditions for applying the measurement method to other metal wires under 1 mm in diameter.
Question_10.Question: What was the second point that needed to be confirmed for each too fine or fragile wire?
Question_10.A: Whether the wire can be fastened by grippers under an initial load
Question_10.B: Whether testing forces can be increased with an increasing stroke increment
Question_10.C: Whether the wire can be elongated uniformly
Question_10.D: Whether the wire can sustain large tensile loads
Question_10.Source: The second is whether testing forces can be increased with an increasing stroke increment while a cross-head is elevated without slippage.
